title: What would you suggest I add to this bootdisk?

forumNotes.author: tummychow
forumNotes.content:
I've put together a fairly solid flash drive for recovery and getting back stuff. Right now, I have the following live disks on it:  

System Rescue CD 2.0.1  
Clonezilla 1.2.6-59  
Acronis True Image Home 2010 Recovery Disk  
BackTrack 4 R2 (still working on this one, it doesn't run yet)  
Parted Magic 5.10  
Ophcrack 2.3.1 (XP and Vista/7 tables loaded)  
Offline NT password and registry editor  
Memtest 4.20 (it comes with a lot of other disks, but I like having it on my boot menu)  
DBAN 2.2.6  
Live Hacking CD 1.2  
Ubuntu 10.10 Desktop  
(menu.lst entries available if anyone wants them, but I copied most of them from elsewhere. Everything tested with QEMU.)  

Anyway, what I'd like to ask is what would you add to this disk? I have 16GB of which only about 4-5GB is used by the above, so there's plenty of room to work with. I try to avoid redundancy in ISOs; multiple disks doing the same thing is usually a waste of space to me. What would you add to it?

forumNotes.author: Sha0
forumNotes.content: A **ReadMe.txt** file with your notes about the directory structure and any customizations that were made to the images in order to facilitate their use with your flash drive... Maybe including references to web-sites for source files/instructions you followed.

forumNotes.author: tummychow
forumNotes.content:
oops. got one =\]  
I use it as the root-finding file so I don't have to search for really long-winded paths to kernels when setting the root disk; it also has a quick rundown of all the stuff I have on the disk and the basis of how I made it work.

forumNotes.author: pajenn
forumNotes.content:
if feasible for you, i'd add a small \~1 GB VHD version of Windows XP and a \~2 GB VHD version of Windows 7. You can use wimb's IMG_XP to make those, but it's still very much a work in progress and of course you'd need the proper source ISO's. Plus I'd install any search, copy, recovery, backup, defrag, registry, mbr, partition, anti-malware, your favorite web browser, and any other tools you might need or that you normally use a lot (for convenience). I'd also add Win7PE with similar plugins in case the VHDs fail to boot. In fact, that's what I have on my own 16 GB emergency flash drive, plus a bunch of drivers and portable apps.  

Search and copy tools are important since often you need to search for some important files and then copy them to an external drive. I like Everything search and Locate32 for searching and FastCopy for copying. Imdisk and Pismo File Mount are all-around convenient, small, free tools for mounting images, and you probably need 7-zip or similar in case you need to open archives. Personally I like to install all the basic everyday programs I normally use onto my emergency OS's to make using them convenient.
